samples.text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a moderately prosocial but self-oriented conditional cooperator with high volatility. They do not anchor on a single contribution level; instead, they frequently shift between very low and very high contributions. They clearly understand that contributing can be profitable when others also contribute, because they repeatedly choose high contributions in environments where group contributions appear strong. At the same time, they are comfortable free-riding and sometimes take the full endowment while still benefiting from others’ cooperation.

Their contributions track the perceived cooperativeness of the group in a broad, qualitative way: when others as a whole appear generous, the player is generally willing to join in, though rarely as the most altruistic member. When the group seems more mixed or deteriorating, they reduce their own contribution sharply, sometimes down to zero, even if cooperation has not completely collapsed. They do not insist on strict equality or fairness; they tolerate contributing more than many low contributors around them at times, and at other times they themselves are among the least generous while others are still contributing substantially. This suggests weak or flexible fairness norms: they care about payoff-relevant conditions (is it lucrative to contribute now?) more than about matching others exactly.

Risk-wise, the player shows a willingness to “gamble” on high contributions when the environment looks cooperative, accepting the immediate personal sacrifice for the expectation of a good group return. However, they do not sustain high contributions unconditionally. Their pattern indicates a payoff-sensitive, opportunistic stance rather than a principled commitment to cooperation or a strict free-riding strategy.

Overall, they are a payoff-oriented conditional cooperator: willing to support the public good when it seems profitable and somewhat socially supported, but quick to scale back and free-ride when they sense fragility or unevenness in group contributions. Their strategy is adaptive rather than rigid, but also noisy and inconsistent, suggesting that they update heuristically rather than following a clear, stable rule.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player appears aware that the game has a finite horizon, but they do not exhibit a simple linear decay or a pure “end-spurt” of defection. In the final portion of the game, they continue to vary their contributions, sometimes contributing very little and sometimes at moderate-to-high levels. They do not switch into a pure defector mode in the last few rounds, nor do they escalate to full cooperation as a final gesture.

Instead, their late-game behavior remains conditional and opportunistic: they adjust contributions up when the group as a whole still looks reasonably cooperative, and they reduce them when the environment seems more mixed or deteriorating, even very close to the final round. This implies that, even when the end is near, their primary reference remains the current cooperative climate and expected payoff, not a strict backward-induction logic or a moral norm about “finishing strong.”

In short, their end-game strategy continues the same pattern as earlier: flexible conditional cooperation with intermittent free-riding, rather than a clear terminal collapse or a final cooperative surge.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a generally cooperative but strategically flexible contributor who oscillates between full cooperation and full free-riding rather than settling into a single stable pattern. They are willing to contribute fully even when others free-ride, and they repeatedly return to full contributions after periods where cooperation in the group has weakened, indicating that they value group efficiency and are not purely self-maximizing.

Their contribution pattern is conditional but not in a strict tit-for-tat sense. They sometimes free-ride when overall cooperation appears unstable or when others explicitly question the point of contributing, yet they also continue to contribute fully in some mixed or partially uncooperative environments. This suggests a “weak conditional cooperator”: they are influenced by group behavior and talk, but they do not mechanically match the group average.

They appear to understand that high collective contributions are beneficial: when others contribute more, they respond positively and are willing to rejoin or sustain high contribution profiles. At the same time, they opportunistically exploit cooperative episodes by withholding their own contribution while benefiting from others’ efforts, showing a non-negligible self-interested streak and comfort with strategic free-riding.

Risk tolerance is moderate. They are willing to risk contributing when others are unreliable, but they also hedge by sometimes choosing zero contributions even when cooperation is possible. Fairness concerns are present but not rigid: they do not visibly protest specific free-riders and occasionally take advantage of generous group behavior themselves, implying a pragmatic rather than moralistic approach to fairness.

Overall, they sit between a pure cooperator and a pure free-rider: generally pro-cooperation, somewhat responsive to the social and strategic context, and prepared to deviate when cooperation seems fragile or “pointless.”

<COMMUNICATION>
The player’s communication style is brief, sociable, and coordination-oriented. They engage in light, informal chat rather than remaining silent, and they direct at least one message toward motivating or cueing a slower or less responsive participant, suggesting a mild leadership or nudging tendency. They frame their prompts in a casual and humorous way rather than confrontationally, which points to a desire to keep the atmosphere friendly while still moving the game along.

They also respond positively when cooperation improves, using upbeat, inclusive language to reinforce a moment of high group contribution. This indicates they pay attention to shifts in group behavior and try to socially reward better coordination through tone rather than through any available sanction or reward mechanisms (which are absent here).

They do not explicitly criticize low contributors or threaten defection, and they do not engage in direct strategic persuasion (such as explaining payoffs or proposing binding agreements). Their engagement is low-to-moderate in volume but clearly indicates attentiveness to others’ pace and to the level of cooperation. They are responsive rather than domineering: they align their remarks with the unfolding chat and group state, suggesting a socially attuned but non-intrusive style.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not lead this player to a clear, monotonic end-game defection pattern. In later rounds, they continue to alternate between full contributions and free-riding rather than moving decisively toward zero contributions as the game approaches its conclusion. They still contribute fully in the very last stage, indicating that they do not rigidly follow the standard backward-induction logic of full defection at the end.

Their later-round behavior remains contingent on perceived group cooperation and on the surrounding tone (“no point” type sentiments from others correlate with some of their defection choices), rather than directly on the countdown of remaining rounds. The horizon appears to be psychologically backgrounded: they know the game length from the interface, but their strategy continues to be driven more by current group behavior and chat signals than by time remaining.

Overall, this player maintains a mixed, context-sensitive strategy through the end of the game. They neither escalate cooperation in a “last push” nor fully abandon it in classic end-game fashion, which suggests that in new PGG environments they are likely to carry their conditional, socially influenced contribution style all the way to the final rounds instead of sharply changing behavior simply because the game is ending.

<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a moderately cooperative, payoff-conscious conditional cooperator who toggles between free-riding, partial contribution, and full contribution. They do not adopt a fixed strategy; instead, they adjust contributions in response to the perceived cooperativeness of the group and to their own payoff experiences.

Their modal choice is an intermediate contribution rather than extremes. They frequently pick a mid-level amount instead of always giving nothing or everything, suggesting they balance self-interest with sustaining group returns. They occasionally fully free-ride, particularly when others are already contributing heavily and group cooperation appears robust, which indicates exploitation of favorable group behavior rather than principled unconditional cooperation. They also periodically contribute their entire endowment when the group appears highly cooperative or when total cooperation seems to surge, consistent with conditional cooperation and a desire to maintain or join high-contribution states.

The pattern shows responsiveness rather than randomness: when cooperation in the group looks strong, they are more willing to contribute high or full amounts; when they observe more low contributors or erratic behavior, they revert to safer mid-level contributions or even zero. This indicates a belief that their own contribution both benefits from and should track what others do, and that over-contributing when others are less cooperative is not worthwhile.

They appear payoff-aware. They experience high payoffs both when they free-ride amid generous others and when they join a highly cooperative group with substantial contributions. They then stay within a band of contributions that maintains good returns without systematically sacrificing personal earnings. This suggests they understand, at least behaviorally, that the marginal per-coin return from the public fund is attractive, but that exploiting others’ generosity occasionally is individually profitable.

There is no evidence of strong fairness enforcement or willingness to “lead” by consistently contributing high regardless of others. Instead, they seem comfortable benefiting from others’ generosity at times and do not consistently match the highest contributors. Their willingness to vacillate between zero, intermediate, and full contributions suggests moderate risk tolerance: they are willing to deviate from whatever the majority seems to do, but not in a purely selfish or purely altruistic direction. They are not rigidly inequality-averse; they accept scenarios where they gain more than heavy contributors and do not subsequently compensate by over-contributing.

Overall, their persona is that of a flexible, opportunistic conditional cooperator: they prefer cooperative, high-contribution environments and will support them with nontrivial or full contributions, but they also strategically exploit such environments by occasional free-riding or dialing down their own contribution when they judge group cooperation to be sufficiently high or fragile.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not produce a pronounced end-game collapse in cooperation for this player. In the final segment of the game, they continue using the same basic repertoire—mostly intermediate contributions with occasional higher ones—rather than sharply dropping to persistent free-riding once the end is near. There is no clear shift to a purely self-regarding, zero-contribution strategy in the final rounds.

Their behavior instead suggests a stable heuristic: maintain moderate contributions in most periods and adjust upward or downward slightly in response to how cooperative the group seems, independent of proximity to the final round. Near the end, they still invest nontrivially in the public fund, implying that they either do not strategically backward-induct or do not prioritize extracting maximal end-game private payoff at the expense of cooperation.

Any subtle changes are small relative to their established pattern. They do not escalate to reliably maximal contributions as a “last gift,” nor do they systematically unwind cooperation. This indicates that while they know how many rounds remain (as per game rules), that knowledge does not dominate their decision-making. They continue to treat late rounds similarly to mid-game, with the same opportunistic yet partially cooperative stance. Their end-game type is therefore “horizon-aware but not horizon-driven”: they may understand the game is ending, but they do not radically change strategy in response.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player fits a “high but strategic cooperator” type. Across the game, they tend to contribute well above the group average, often close to the maximum, but they do not lock into blind full cooperation. Instead, they adjust around a high baseline in response to perceived changes in others’ behavior and the group’s contribution level.

They initially experiment with low and medium contributions before quickly moving into a pattern of strong cooperation. Once they see that many peers are regularly giving substantial amounts, they typically match or slightly exceed the prevailing cooperative norm. They are willing to give the full endowment in many rounds and frequently choose contributions in the upper range, indicating strong pro-social inclination combined with acceptance of the individual cost.

Their contributions are not perfectly stable: they occasionally drop to moderate or even zero contributions. These drops coincide with situations where the group’s contributions are more uneven or where some players free-ride more visibly. This suggests conditional cooperation: they are willing to sustain high giving while others also contribute reasonably, but they temporarily reduce their own contribution when they infer that the environment is drifting toward lower cooperation. However, these lower-contribution episodes are short-lived; they typically revert quickly to high contributions if group cooperation recovers, indicating they prioritize restoring a cooperative equilibrium over retaliatory defection.

They display sensitivity to fairness at the group level. When others are broadly contributing high amounts, they appear comfortable matching that level, and they do not systematically undercut the group. The few low-contribution choices seem more like tests or responses to perceived unfairness than a consistent desire to exploit others.

Their risk tolerance is moderate to high. Given that personal returns from contribution depend on others, they repeatedly accept short-term risk in order to support a high-contribution environment, even after episodes where such generosity yields relatively lower payoffs due to weaker group contributions. They do not show systematic payoff maximization via free-riding; instead, they trade off some individual security for the prospect of higher group payoffs, consistent with a cooperative but strategically aware profile.

Overall, this player is best characterized as a conditional high cooperator: generally generous, responsive to the group’s cooperative climate, and willing to bear individual cost to support high-contribution equilibria, but not fully unconditional.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not trigger a collapse of cooperation for this player. In the late game, including the final rounds, they continue to contribute at high or upper-mid levels rather than shifting into systematic free-riding. There is some fluctuation and a slight tendency to lower from full-max contributions to strong but not maximal amounts, but there is no clear end-game defection wave.

This pattern suggests that they either do not heavily apply backward-induction reasoning or they place substantial weight on cooperative norms and consistency over final-round exploitation. They appear more inclined to “finish cooperatively” than to exploit the final opportunity for personal gain.

Their late-game behavior remains conditional: when the group maintains robust contributions, they sustain high giving; when group contributions are more mixed, they adjust slightly downward but still stay cooperative. The final round continues this rule-based pattern rather than exhibiting a unique, one-off deviation.

In short, their end-game strategy is to keep cooperating at a high level with moderate fine-tuning rather than to abandon cooperation, indicating a stable pro-cooperative orientation that persists even when no future rounds remain.

<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a flexible, payoff-conscious conditional cooperator with intermittent free-riding. They do not commit to a single stable contribution level; instead, they alternate between zero, moderate, and high contributions. Their choices track the overall cooperativeness of the group: they are more willing to contribute when others appear highly cooperative and when the public fund remains strong, and they reduce or drop contributions when they see lower or unstable group contributions.

They clearly recognize the private incentive to free-ride: they repeatedly take the option to contribute nothing while benefiting from substantial group contributions. However, they are not a pure defector; they regularly choose non-minimal contributions, sometimes relatively high ones. This mix suggests they balance personal earnings with some willingness to support group efficiency, rather than following a strict selfish or altruistic rule.

Their contribution pattern is volatile rather than fixed. They move between low and high contributions multiple times, indicating ongoing adjustment rather than a simple early decision. This volatility appears responsive to perceived norms: in phases when many others seem generous, they frequently join in with sizeable contributions; when there is visible heterogeneity or some apparent free-riding by others, they sometimes switch back to low or zero contributions.

They display a weak but present fairness or reciprocity norm. They never systematically match the most cooperative players, but they do seem uncomfortable being purely exploitative for the entire game: after episodes of low giving, they later choose to contribute generously even when they could keep all coins and still benefit from others’ giving. This suggests a limited internal standard of “doing their share,” though that standard is inconsistent.

Risk tolerance appears moderate. The player is willing to “invest” in the public fund in situations where they cannot predict exact future behavior of others but where recent evidence suggests a cooperative environment. At the same time, they often hedge by choosing mid-level contributions rather than always going to the maximum, signaling some caution about overexposure if others defect.

Overall, the player is best described as a strategically adaptive, opportunistic cooperator: they exploit cooperative environments at times but also help sustain them once they trust that others are reliably contributing. Their cooperativeness is conditional, fluctuating with their assessment of the group’s behavior and their own payoff experience.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player is clearly aware of the finite horizon and does not follow a simple “cooperate to the end” rule. In the last several rounds, their contributions remain variable rather than monotonically declining or increasing. They sometimes contribute substantial amounts close to the end, but they also intersperse zero contributions, including in the final round.

There is no consistent pattern of escalating generosity or systematic end-game defection. Instead, their late-game behavior looks like a continuation of their earlier conditional style: they respond to the current cooperative climate more than to the abstract fact that the game is ending. When others remain relatively cooperative late in the game, the player is still willing to contribute non-trivially in some of those rounds, despite having no future rounds in which reputation or reciprocation can pay off. At the same time, they seize opportunities to free-ride near the end, including at the very last possible decision.

This combination suggests that horizon awareness is present but not dominant. The player does not appear to run a backward-induction strategy; instead, they treat late rounds largely like earlier ones, with slightly more readiness to defect opportunistically when the payoff from free-riding is salient. Their cooperation does not collapse entirely as the end approaches, but it becomes more selective and interspersed with full defection, consistent with an adaptive type that weighs immediate payoff opportunities more heavily than long-run relational concerns once the horizon is short.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is best described as a *calculating opportunistic free-rider with occasional exploratory cooperation*. Their default tendency is to give nothing to the public fund even when others are fully cooperative, and they maintain this stance for most of the game. Contributions are generally low and infrequent, with two notable deviations where they give a substantial amount. This pattern suggests they primarily prioritize personal payoff over efficiency or equality, only temporarily deviating from that to test or experience more cooperative outcomes.

Their behavior is highly conditional on others’ actions in a narrow, self-focused way: they appear to take others’ unwavering full contributions as an exploitable resource rather than as a norm to reciprocate. However, the fact that they do sometimes make large contributions indicates they are not a pure, rigid free-rider. Instead, they seem capable of experimenting with higher contributions, perhaps to see the payoff consequences or to gauge how the mechanism works, but they do not sustain such behavior.

There is no indication that they are aiming at fairness in the sense of matching others’ contributions or equalizing payoffs. They consistently benefit from others’ generosity without reciprocating in a stable way. This suggests a weak or absent internal fairness norm within the game context, at least behaviorally. If any fairness concern exists, it does not override their inclination to exploit the cooperative environment.

Their risk tolerance appears moderate to low: once they see that others contribute maximally and that they can safely free-ride, they largely stick to the safe, high-private-payoff strategy, with only a couple of higher-contribution deviations that look more exploratory than risk-seeking for social reasons. They do not appear to fear retaliation or breakdown of cooperation, possibly because no punishment is available and others’ behavior remains perfectly stable.

Overall, their contribution pattern is stable in its free-riding core but punctuated by a small number of sizable, short-lived cooperative moves, which look like tests or curiosity-driven changes rather than commitment to a cooperative norm.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows awareness of the game horizon but does not use it to gradually reduce cooperation; instead, they maintain a predominantly free-riding strategy throughout and briefly escalate cooperation before returning to free-riding at the very end. There is no classic pattern of declining contributions as the end approaches, because sustained cooperation is never really established from their side.

In the late phase, they temporarily switch to high contributions and then abruptly revert to giving nothing on the final decision. This suggests that, when the end is clearly in sight, they still prioritize their own last-round payoff over any desire to maintain a cooperative pattern. The final move is consistent with end-game defection logic: with no future interaction, they feel no incentive to continue contributing.

Their brief late-game cooperative surge does not translate into a “cooperation ramp” or a stable end-game strategy. Instead, it looks like a short experiment that they quickly abandon when it directly conflicts with maximizing their final payoff. There is no behavioral sign that they are motivated to leave a “good impression” or end on a prosocial note; the terminal choice is self-serving and aligns with their broader opportunistic type.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a calculated, profit-oriented “selective free-rider” who flexibly switches between full contribution and full defection, with no middle levels available. They do not settle into a stable cooperative or non-cooperative identity; instead, they alternate contributions in a way that keeps their own earnings relatively high while relying heavily on others’ sustained cooperation.

They consistently exploit cooperative environments: when the group’s average contribution remains high, they frequently choose not to contribute and thereby secure strictly higher payoffs than most contributors. Their contribution decisions show no clear matching or fairness norm (e.g., they do not “reward” others’ high contributions by reliably joining them, nor do they visibly punish low contributors by withdrawing support). Rather than aiming for equality of payoffs, they appear comfortable being among the highest earners at others’ expense.

Their pattern suggests low concern for outcome fairness and relatively low guilt or discomfort about free-riding. At the same time, they do sometimes contribute even when free-riding would be immediately more profitable, indicating either: (a) some concern for maintaining the group’s cooperative level over time, or (b) experimentation and mild strategic uncertainty. The alternation of contributions, rather than a monotone decline or rise, is consistent with opportunistic adjustment to a setting where others prove reliably generous.

Risk tolerance appears moderate: they are willing to contribute in an environment where others occasionally defect, but they do not persist in cooperative behavior when it is clearly unnecessary for them to profit. With a very high multiplier and consistently high group contributions, they know that even if they defect, they still gain large returns from the public pool. Their main orientation is toward maximizing own payoff under that favorable background, not toward sustaining cooperation at personal cost.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
This player shows horizon awareness but does not exhibit a classic end-game collapse into universal defection. In the late game, they continue to mix between contributing and not contributing rather than simply free-riding to the finish. There is no sharp shift toward lower contributions as the final round approaches, which suggests that their strategy is not driven by a simple “cooperate early, defect late” heuristic.

Instead, they maintain the same basic opportunistic pattern they display earlier: sometimes contributing when the group is already cooperative, sometimes defecting to capture extra gains. They do not try to “cash out” by switching exclusively to free-riding at the end, nor do they “make up for” earlier free-riding by ending on a more prosocial note in a way that sacrifices clear monetary advantage. Their end-game behavior is consistent with a player who already believes they have extracted value effectively throughout the game and simply continues their existing rule rather than re-optimizing specifically for the final rounds.

Overall, end-game awareness is present (they know how many rounds remain), but there is no strong evidence of either end-game altruism or a last-round defection spike. The end period looks like a continuation of an already opportunistic approach rather than a qualitatively new phase.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player observes others’ contributions and payoffs each round and appears to learn that the group is persistently cooperative. Once this is clear, they repeatedly choose actions that exploit that cooperativeness: they free-ride in many situations where others are almost unanimously contributing, obtaining higher payoffs than almost all peers. This indicates that they respond to others’ outcomes by taking advantage of the predictability and generosity of the environment, rather than by reciprocating.

They do not show clear conditional cooperation in the classic sense: they do not reliably increase their own contributions when others are generous, nor do they cut back when they see a few defectors still earning high payoffs. Their willingness to continue contributing in a highly cooperative but exploitable group suggests that their primary response to others’ outcomes is not emotional (e.g., anger at free-riders) but instrumental: they contribute or not depending on whether they see a personal advantage or at least no clear disadvantage in maintaining a cooperative baseline.

Because there is no punishment or reward mechanism in this environment, we see no direct evidence of how they would spend resources to change others’ payoffs. However, from their comfortable free-riding on high contributors, the most plausible extrapolation is that they do not prioritize sanctioning or rewarding behavior in general; they treat others’ payoffs mainly as background conditions that create opportunities for themselves. Empathy for those who earn less, or resentment toward those who defect, is not evident from their choices; their behavior stays focused on their own earnings, relatively insensitive to whether specific peers are slightly advantaged or disadvantaged in a given round.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mixed, strategically opportunistic cooperator with a bias toward free-riding when the group is reliably cooperative. They alternate between full contribution and full defection rather than using intermediate or noisy patterns, indicating a clear, discrete strategy choice instead of random fluctuation. Early on, they are willing to contribute fully even when some others free-ride, suggesting they accept short-term disadvantage to help maintain a high group return. As the game progresses and it becomes clear that the group sustains high contributions without sanction mechanisms, they increasingly exploit this by withholding their own contribution while continuing to benefit from others’ cooperation. Their choices show awareness of the payoff structure: they contribute in many rounds but regularly insert defection rounds to boost personal payoffs, especially once group behavior appears stable and predictable. They do not appear to adhere to strict equality or reciprocity norms; they tolerate receiving more than consistent cooperators and do not visibly “correct” that by over-contributing later. Overall, they prioritize personal earnings while still contributing often enough to support the public good, resembling a calculated conditional cooperator who leans toward self-interest rather than a pure altruist or pure free-rider. Risk attitude is moderately cautious: they seldom defect in ways that would obviously destabilize the group, instead free-riding opportunistically while others keep contributions high.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player is clearly horizon-aware and adjusts behavior near the end. They do not follow a simple “end-game collapse” script where they stop contributing as the final rounds approach. Instead, their late-game behavior is non-monotonic: they defect in some late rounds but also return to full contribution, including in the final round. This suggests they track remaining rounds yet do not purely backward-induct to universal defection. Their willingness to contribute at the very end, even after having successfully free-ridden in other late rounds, indicates that they do not operate on a strict “last chance to exploit” mindset. Possible motives (uncertain) include maintaining a cooperative self-image, avoiding being the most obvious exploiter, or simply following a mixed strategy they see as balanced. There is no evidence of escalating selfishness right at the horizon; instead, their pattern remains one of alternating exploitation and cooperation, with end-game effects present but not dominant.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player is sensitive to the general cooperation level and to how others’ actions affect payoffs, but the response is aggregate rather than individually targeted. They see that many peers contribute consistently and receive slightly lower payoffs than defectors, yet they are willing to occupy the higher-payoff, lower-contribution niche without any compensating behavior. This implies a relatively low concern for strict payoff fairness and a comfort with benefiting more than those who contribute as much or more to the public good. At the same time, they do not push their exploitation to an extreme; they continue contributing frequently, which helps sustain high group outcomes. The absence of punishment and reward in this environment means we cannot observe any direct response to others’ outcomes via sanctions or bonuses; their adaptation happens only through their own contribution choices. When group contributions remain strong despite some defections, they respond by inserting more free-riding rounds, indicating they track that cooperators are “absorbing” the cost without collapsing. Conversely, when cooperation levels are very high, they are also willing to fully contribute, suggesting they value the high common return and may feel some obligation or strategic need to maintain it. Overall, they appear attuned to the payoff consequences of others’ actions but prioritize exploiting favorable group behavior over enforcing norms or equalizing outcomes.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mostly conditional cooperator with opportunistic free-riding. After beginning as a pure defector, they shift into a pattern where they often match or exceed the group’s cooperative baseline but intermittently exploit cooperative periods by keeping their endowment. Contribution choices are binary and used flexibly rather than rigidly; they neither lock into always-give nor always-keep. They seem sensitive to whether “enough” others are contributing and are more willing to contribute when the broader environment is cooperative and somewhat stable. When others’ behavior becomes erratic or more selfish, they do not respond with a clear, consistent retaliation rule; instead, they sometimes keep contributing and other times free-ride, suggesting low but present concern for fairness and a stronger focus on personal payoff than on strict reciprocity.

Their strategy suggests they understand that contributing in a cooperative environment can be individually profitable, yet they are comfortable deviating to defection even when others are largely cooperative. They exhibit moderate risk tolerance: they are willing to contribute when others seem likely to cooperate, but they also periodically “test” how much they can gain by deviating. The pattern indicates they value both group efficiency and personal advantage, with the balance tilting toward self-interest when a one-shot gain is available and no punishment is present. Stability is medium: they show phases of sustained cooperation punctuated by isolated defections rather than random noise. They do not show strong commitment to equality of outcomes; they are willing to earn more than others when free-riding on their contributions.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player does not send any chat messages. Their style is purely observational and non-verbal. They receive multiple social signals from others, including impatience, humor, and mild attempts to coordinate faster or more cooperative play, yet they never respond directly. This suggests a low-engagement or avoidant communication style: they do not use messages to persuade, negotiate, justify their actions, or enforce norms.

Despite the silence, their behavior adjusts after periods when group members express a desire for coordination and higher contributions, implying that they register social cues but choose not to participate overtly. They appear to treat chat primarily as background information about group mood and likely behavior, not as a channel they themselves want to use. This muted presence can make them harder to read and holds down any social accountability that might come from promising or explaining their strategy. Overall, they are a quiet, reactive observer rather than an active conversational leader.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not produce a simple monotonic end-game collapse in cooperation. In the late part of the game, the player alternates between cooperation and defection rather than clearly ramping down contributions. They do exploit some late opportunities to free-ride when others continue to cooperate, showing that they are willing to cash in on the absence of future repercussions. At the same time, they also continue to contribute in other late rounds, including the final one, even when a purely self-interested, backward-induction logic would predict consistent defection.

This pattern suggests that they understand the temptation to defect near the end and act on it intermittently, but they do not adhere to a strict end-game defection rule. Their behavior is better described as opportunistic than fully time-consistent: they look for profitable deviations but still maintain significant cooperative behavior up to and including the last round. The absence of punishment or reward mechanisms appears to make them comfortable taking advantage of cooperative others in select late rounds, but it does not completely erase their willingness to contribute. Their horizon sensitivity is thus present but moderate, producing fluctuating rather than steadily declining cooperation near the end.

<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a moderately cooperative, payoff-sensitive conditional cooperator with sizeable free-riding tendencies. Their typical contribution sits in the mid range rather than at the extremes: they neither consistently exploit others by always giving nothing nor commit to strong unconditional cooperation. Contributions vary with the apparent cooperativeness of the group: when others appear to contribute more on average, they are willing to increase their own giving into the mid-to-high range; when others appear to contribute little, they pull back sharply or even drop to zero. This pattern indicates conditional cooperation anchored more on relative than absolute fairness: they seem comfortable contributing less than the highest contributors while still participating in the public good. They display clear responsiveness to payoffs—they sometimes experiment with higher contributions, but when these trials produce visibly lower payoffs for them relative to low-contribution rounds, they reduce later contributions. Their risk tolerance for being a “sucker” is limited; they rarely position themselves at the top of the contribution distribution for the group and often remain at or below the group mean. Over time, they maintain cooperation at a moderate level rather than escalating it, suggesting a preference for balancing earnings with some degree of group-oriented behavior.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player is aware of the finite horizon and exhibits a mild but clear end-game effect. In the middle and later stages, when cooperation in the group looks relatively strong, they are willing to contribute at or above their own typical mid-level, signaling that they do not immediately unravel cooperation as the final rounds approach. However, their final-round decision shows a decisive shift toward self-interest, with a contribution that is lower than their established mid-range tendency despite the presence of many cooperative peers. This indicates that, while they are willing to sustain cooperation close to the end when it seems profitable and socially supported, they ultimately prioritize maximizing their final payoff once there is no future interaction. The decay is not gradual and systematic from the midpoint onward; rather, it appears as a late-stage strategic drop that reflects horizon awareness and a willingness to free-ride when future repercussions are absent. Overall, they are an end-game defector who cooperates conditionally up to very near the end, then opportunistically withdraws contribution in the last opportunity.

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is primarily a high, almost unconditional cooperator who occasionally experiments with defection. For the overwhelming majority of the game, they contribute the maximum possible amount regardless of whether others do the same. Their cooperation is only weakly conditional: when some group members free‑ride repeatedly, the player still continues to contribute fully most of the time instead of matching or undercutting them. They do, however, test defection a couple of times after a long run of full cooperation, indicating they are not a pure altruist; they are willing to see what happens when they keep their endowment, even after having helped maintain a cooperative norm.

Their fairness norm is pro‑group but relaxed. They clearly prefer full-contribution outcomes and express appreciation when a previous low contributor starts contributing.
